text: Not really that¬†impressed with this as a luxury car as I thought¬†I might have¬†been. There are different kinds of luxury that¬†one ¬†might desire or need,¬† but¬†it seem that the motor car industry today is using the latest gimmicks and gadgets¬†to sell their luxury cars. Most of what they offer is of very little use to me or many other¬†motorists, who simply want a very practical luxurious car, not a pile of gadgets that will¬†impress me¬†and will have very little use in the long run.¬†I am amazed how many people will buy a car that is very expensive,¬†because it is loaded with gadgets and gimmicks, that not¬†only complicate the car, but can make the car an extremely expensive item to repair and maintain, and then¬†worry about fuel economy. In the early 70's I owned a Jaguar XJ6 and people would ask me constantly about the fuel economy. My stock response was¬†¬†"If I was worried about the fuel economy I would have bought a Mini."¬†Others told me that they did not like it because it was too quiet and far too smooth and comfortable. Now my point here is that I respected and understood where they were coming from, even though the modern cars of today have caught up to my old Jaguar. However the real point I am making here is¬†that there was a big choice back then, ¬†between the cheap bumpy car and one that offered me a real luxurious interior and a beautiful soft ride. Today one can spend a small fortune for a rougher riding with sports suspension,¬†with the latest gadgets and gimmicks¬†that I might never use.¬†This is why I now find the best value for money is the cheaper Asian cars which are more dependable than most so called luxury cars. I have a Toyota and I also¬†have a 1996 Jaguar XJ6¬†which is near new condition.

text: I know a lot of people complain about Tesla‚Äôs interior but keep in mind Tesla is more of a technology vehicle rather than a luxury vehicle. So yes you might not get the best interior but you get a lot of other things that cars around the same price don‚Äôt have for example they come with air suspension so you can adjust the ride height, summon so you can move the vehicle back and forth from tight spots, Tesla phone app so you can set temperatures, track the vehicle in real time, home link which enables your garage to open and the Tesla to park itself or exit out of the garage with nobody inside, Autopilot so it drives it self in the highway or long roads, and they even include an 8 year unlimited mileage for the battery, and the best thing is that it doesn‚Äôt require maintenance like a bmw, Mercedes, etc. Theirs no such thing as oil changes, transmission fluids things of that sort which luxury manufactures will rip you off. They also get software updates like you phone so the car essentially improves over time as well as the maps and some functions unlike a normal car where you have to pay about $200 just to get updated maps. And a Tesla typically cost about $10 to fill up with electricity to give you anywhere from 260miles to 335 miles of distance rather than paying 40-50 at the pump for a full range. So overall yes a Tesla is not going to have a nice interior like a Mercedes or bmw but in my opinion the Tesla will have more bang to you buck and keep in mind a Mercedes Benz S550 starts at 96k while the Tesla starts at 78k and will our perform the S550 in speed, safety, and ride quality.

text:
If that's the future of Luxury, I don't want to be in that future. 

What kind of bland future is that? How many square tablets do you need in front of you? Sensory overload while driving? 

Improve Augmented Reality, Over Head Display tech, and Head Up Display tech. Remove these tablet type displays which will be obsolete in the next 3 years.

Stop the "Bigger display than yours wars...", who cares about 13 inch screen, when the whole windscreen could be your AR real estate. With improved sign recognition, hazard detection, zoom, facial recognition, immersive night vision. Sci-fi? Stop playing now, our phones are smaller than a car, and can already do most of these things. Stop ripping people off, 3 years at a time!

text: The screen you referred to as "Head Up Display", is not HUD. HUD is a sort of augmented reality that displays the information literally on the road in front of you. It is something that Tesla definitely should deliver as standard for the price they are charging for Model S and X. And if they don't step up their game in terms of interior cabin, they will have some serious trouble competing because companies who have more than 60 years experience of building cars, will not disappoint with their cabins. Especially Germans manufacturers, which are planning to launch their first generation EV in the next two years. Funny thing is that Tesla has succeeded with the most difficult part (high tech) of manufacturing and it's these little low tech stuff they are lacking behind with. Which on the other hand shouldn't be a problem because it is low tech challenge.

text:
There is a lot going for this design if they can ever get their $#!+ together, especially in the realm of autonomous driving.
I can completely see a car where the owners of the car sit in the back and the "passengers" sit up front.  Especially if you have kids.  Spin those small front seats around for when you don't have to do any manual driving at all and this platform suddenly makes a whole lot of sense.  The trunk is in the front.
We are going to see some crazy adoption numbers as the range keeps climbing on these and as autonomous driving takes hold.

text: It's not to say Lucid can do well. They can. But let's also not forget that Tesla can very easily upgrade their interior to surpass even the lucid, there's no copyright on level of luxury. The financial backing, the hype - Tesla has a robust ecosystem surrounding them to steamroll over current competition. That is if they don't fall over themselves. As interesting as the Licid is, it's currently a glorified concept car. They have a long way to go, a smart and strategic partnership with other auto makers might make this very interesting. So many possibilities. Bravo to hem for raising the bar on what can be accomplished with design though, awe inspiring...

text:
cons: headlights are literally of no use on a highway during night. 
Passengers will get alot lot of sunlight. even if they don't need it. the glass on roof thing will not work in equatorial countries like India, etc. because it will receive a huge amount of sunlight.
author: Shaunak Shetye

text:
If those are your biggest cons, you better start saving for one. 
LED headlights can be any shape or size, we are just used to the big round shape that was needed for decades in order to have a bulb and mirror in there. Just go to the store and look at how strong a cheap LED flashlight can be. 
About the glass, if you  listen to the commentary, they say the roof is gonna be polarised, so you can make it opaque. And that's not future tech, it's been in higher end Mercs with glass roofs for some years now; they just haven't put it in the prototype yet. There's literally no car with a clear glass roof that can't be covered or dimmed somehow, so why do you think this would be the first?

text: Lucid Motors = Faraday Future?

text:
NO just NOPE. Lucid Motors formerly Atieva.
Majority share holder is Beijing Automotive Industry Corporation.
author: Neojhun

text: Isn't Faraday Future mostly funded by a Chinese corporation?
author: Road to the 2 Comma Club

text:
Not really a corporation. It's a pet project by the LeEco founder Jia Yueting. He is not just an investor, he is involved in the business operation of Faraday Futures now. In 2014 Jia Yueting invested minority share in Atieva with no operational involvement, since they were bought over by BAIC & changed into Lucid Motors. It cause quite a lot of difficulty and drama. Seems like Jia Yueting sold off and left Lucid.
FYI China is not one entity in reality.
author: Neojhun

text: So the guy who invested in Faraday Futures was once involved in Lucid Motors?
author: Road to the 2 Comma Club

text: Jia Yueting was just a minority investor hedging his bets and gaining access to most advance people in the industry. Smart move, but he left.

text: Touch screens are nice, but buttons are still where it's at. When driving, it's easier (and safer) to have actual tactile buttons/knobs as physical cues. Less distracting and safer to operate because they will not require any or quite as much looking and searching to use. I'm not saying all one or the other, I'm just saying that the most commonly used functions should be tactile, everything else can be buried into the touch interface.

text: Although I cannot afford it at all, the wrap-around windshield would be a deal-breaker if it didn't have that ability to tint.  I imagine lying down in those great bucket seats in the back and closing my eyes, and sun is shining right in my face.  Even driving, sun would be in my face.  It's hard enough for me when the sun is getting low.  And even when the sun is high up, I often move my arms away from where the sun is shining on them.  Yes, I know I sound like a vampire, but I'm glad there will be a tint option (if I ever were in the market for it).

text:
My only concern is.. if the interior is so luxury and so stylish... why isnt the exterior like that? the exterior is so plain and just looks like another random car on the street. If someone is paying a premium price.. they want it to look premium as well! (I know looks are subjective and you may have a different opinion on how it looks) I don't think it will be a successful model. 

Look at Tesla models.. model 3 is focused on everyday use and normal looking car while the roadster looks more sporty and high end electric car. See a clear distinction in looks and uses and prices targeted at different consumer! 

But this Lucid Air model just seems all confused as to what kind of customer they are targeting and in my opinion it wont be very successful yet very important as it will pave the way for luxury electric cars.

text: I love the interior and am tentative about the exterior. I also don't know about glass that's not made out of polycarbonate material. It's just way too fragile and breakable. Plus there was a case here in the US where four teenagers threw a brick off an overpass that smashed through a woman's windshield and permanently disabled her. Her husband was so distraught that a year later he shot himself and died. Prosecutors were at a loss about what to do and even wanted to charge the teenagers for also causing the husband to commit suicide as a result of his wife's permanent disability. Sad case all the way around. Makes me really want to have strong and practically bulletproof polycarbonate glass on every vehicle. Because you never know what stupid 17-year-old is right around the corner. Smh.

text: Perfect Cell think of it like this; automobiles have certain criteria they have to meet to be deemed road-worthy. crash safety tests are one of them. this glass isn't like the glass on your coffee table or in your cupboard; this is Plexiglas. it's not going to shatter and start cutting your skin off. it's one of the most resilient clear materials in production, you'd have to hit it really hard to even puncture it.

text:
You gotta try and be less bias in your car reviews. 
First of all you need to be more skeptical of their claims, start up companies, especially tech companies, and car companies both like to make a ton of claims then deliver on very few of them, which means absolutely everything they tell you, you need to find out what's true, and what's hopes and dreams. For example the 1000bhp figure. 

Then, you gotta be less bias. For example, you said its a fair trade to have less leg room for more trunk space. No it isnt. Its an expensive luxury car, that means no compromises. Why the hell didn't they just make the body longer? Also the screen folds away, thats cool but it didn't seem to fold away completely which is super ugly, and again another compromise. When reviewing a car that'll probably cost a few hundred thousand dollars, you need to point out every little bad thing about it. Finally for a "high tech futuristic" car those screens sure had really massive ugly bezels. Makes me think they probably arent terrible modern either, Are they OLED 1444p? or are they the same shit that all other cars have. 

Finally you need to do more research. I mean you clearly arent a car review channel, your a tech channel, and maybe you dont want to just copy other peoples car review, you want to make it your own. But you admitted to yourself that you don't understand why the tesla false short in the luxury department, probably because you've never driven or taken a close look at other luxury cars. I mean if the tesla is 100k already then this must be 2-3 hundred thousand. Its not going against luxury sedans, its going against the v12 class of luxury cars. Bentleys, Rolls royce, S65, 760Li etc. Have you ever been close up with any of those cars? Do you know what to look for in a luxury car? Do you know what differentiated an 550i from a rolls royce ghost? 

This was a great video, but it could have been much better and more informed if you a, did a bit of research before hand and b, added in a bit of negatives for all of the positives.

author: Ruben Braekman

text:
Glass is actually an important part of the structural integrity, hence why many insurance companies give discounts/cover the cost of wind shield repair. On standard vehicles, the glass is designed to absorb impacts and disperse it, and it has layers of film coating it so that when it does shatter, it doesn't rain glass.

More over, in a situation where the car rolls over, the protection will come from the A/B/C pillars.  

Finally, the Department of Transportation (the agency that mandates road safety features) already road-certified this vehicle :)

text:
Steven Williams 

Pass on electrics until gas gets to $5/gallon or government forces me to. Automotive enthusiasts hate electrics and hybrid. No engine and noise. It's cold and clinical, with no emotion from the roar and rumble of a gas motor. 

Also, there's no logical mass charging infrastructure that every EV can use. Mining lithium and cobalt requires strip and quarry mining. Plus lots of places are using dirty fuels like coal and diesel to power the electrical grid, more so now in the US with the President and ruling party committed to bringing back coal and decrease regulation on fossil fuels.

author: Neo Smith

text:
Neo Smith well excuse me for worrying about my own life.

Who wouldn't buy this LUXURY car for safety?Sure it's fast, but It's not a Ferrari or a TVR. It's just not a track car. I never new that luxury and safety had to be mutually exclusive.
author: Sean M.

text:
Oh yeah have you seen a convertible, there are plenty of those in luxury car industry (actually those are mainly in the luxury car industry) those things don't even have roof. Not to mention those glass are not made of the one that they use to make your glass of water.

Safety does not mean a bunker that would protect your life even if you drive off a 20 m cliff.
author: lcbp2009

text:
I never said a convertible was any better, I would never drive one, and most ultra-luxury cars with actual room inside have roofs. And I know how strong glass can be. It is much harder than steel, but in any sort of crash, rigid, brittle glass is worthless. If it were some sort of composite with some flexibility (who knows maybe it is!) then it would actually be very good. 

Also I'm pretty sure convertibles are mainly in the sporty market, at least like literally everywhere I have seen them.

I'm not sure why just because I state a thing I don't like about a car people have to assume I want a tank to shelter me from a thermonuclear bomb. But that's the internet!
author: Sean M.

text: Those convertible pass car crash test that's why they're on the road. By saying a car is not safe just because it doesn't have a roof make it sound like you require that a car need to be able to protect you in case it is turn completly upside down. Which, I'm pretty sure, no car is designed to be like that, there is no "tip over car crash test". Not to mention those advanced car are more focus on the "not getting you into an accident" part, which personally for me is the right way to do it. So just because a car doesn't have a roof or it's roof is made out of glass doesn't mean it is less safe compare to a car with a roof.
author: lcbp2009

text:
There actually are rollover tests(mainly for vehicles with high ground clearance) and roof strength tests. No car would ever be ranked very high without passing them. A good roof certainly can be helpful, although not vital in all scenarios.
Also i said I would never FEEL safe in a car like that. That doesn't mean I don't think it could possibly be safe, I'm sure the people at Lucid care about that a lot. But I also don't want my life taken by some idiot on the road, so I'm just wary of something that seems questionable, and a glass roof definitely is questionable to me.
author: Sean M.

text: @Sean Mcnamara : Indeed there is roll over car crash test, on that matter I stand corrected, I was looking at the official requirement and didn't see anything. Turns out some companies do perform them as an additionnal test. As for the roof strength test I already saw that but didn't considered it as a real roll over test, not to mention the car also has a metal frame on it's roof so it was not sure whether it would pass the roof strength test or not. I'm just saying, the fact that the car has roof made of glass doesn't necessary means it is less safer compare to a metal one, not to mention if you follow all the rules the chance that you roll over is almost none.

text: Their website says $52,000 for the base model, which would make it decisively cheaper than a Tesla Model S. I'm hoping that's true, that they stick to that super competitive pricing. I love Tesla and what Elon Musk is doing, but with a serious competitor offering a compelling and competitive product, that's going to start shifting the electric auto industry into gear, with newcomers popping up and offering stuff like this, and the old guard such as Chevy, Kia, Honda, Ford, Lexus, Audi, Mercedes, etc, jumping in on electric autos. Which, mentioning Elon Musk, I guess is something he'd want to see too. Nothing to get the world into electric cars faster than cut throat market competition.

text: Wow, all that dynamic technology makes me really think about how much I stare into computer and I think to myself that maybe everyone goes...damn, when I see a screen I want to stare at it and play videos and games and touch it constantly! So, for me that's something that really makes me feel uncertain about those features and pedestrian safety. Maybe I'm just a little over sensitive to the issues because I haven't really driven a car in like 8 years but I like n/p features where digital based on plastic odometers of the past just kinda light up...I'm into rat bikes and bobbers so my color ways aren't extreme and I really barely use a safety cell phone and I'm pretty much a shopper online and use it to watch judge Judy reruns and play some music when I'm not at the gym and around the house...I just really didn't dig the car too much..it seemed over dramatically expansive inside..I like roomy but it just seemed vacant and dangerously so and the car just looks like it's screaming for a drone based drive technology and just bland...like maybe it should say kd or Jordan on the side and have alligator print on the trim or a gold plastic bumper! Just kind of a blah car and a mm..feeling except for the charger...which makes me kinda go...umm...turn it off so it doesn't die???? Just my first impression...make it black and put a smooth character in it on a wet black plastic floor and play electro music and call me. Blah...

Ridesharing? Is it really the future? 
I don't want and will never want other people, who I don't know, get into my car. I love technology, but sometimes it seems like technology companies pick on a famous word, and make is sound like it's very important to people. It's not. Don't lose reality.
Like airbnb, there are some people who allow others to use their home to make some money, most people will never let a stranger in their house. Same thing with cars. I want MY car to be MY property.

author: Mat√≠as Vidal

text: Get out of here with your regressive bullshit. Gasoline powered cars are going to be extinct and I welcome their demise.
author: Adam Tak

text: Mat√≠as Vidal and yet the McLaren P1 and the Porsche 918 and the LaFerrari are all hybrids. As much as you hate it companies are starting to realize this and are moving in that direction.
author: Christian Ramos

text: Christian Ramos True, but if you think about it, hybrid cars are meant to be more ecological, the idea is to put an electric motor and an internal combustion engine (a little one, thats the purpose of hybrids) into a car so they car work together and create a car that's more ecological with less emissions but with similar power outputs as a regular internal combustion car. What Maclaren, Porsche and Ferrari did was brilliant. They took the hybrid car concept and used it to create an awesome super fast hyper car, giving a shit about emissions and the environment, they took advantage of the electric motor design (initially built for the planet's sake) and used it so an internal combustion powered car could be even more powerful. So, car companies are not planning to move on to electric motors yet, at least these 3, they are trying to keep the old designs alive using the new ones in their favour
author: Mat√≠as Vidal

text: Adam Tak Cars are gonna turn into a big couch with wheels if what you're saying is true. What's the point of that?
author: Mat√≠as Vidal

text: Mat√≠as Vidal the point of a car is to get you from point A to point B. My girlfriend lives 10 hours away from me and once a month I make the drive there and it sucks ass. If I could read a book or watch Netflix during the drive, that would make it so much better. Now having a sports car for driving back ways with hundreds of turns and curves, that's more fun and less about actual transportation
author: Horace Christenson the III

text: Horace Christenson the III Well obviously, that was the initial reason for building a car, and I get it, I wouldn't like to drive 10 hours straight once a month. But that's just one side of the story, it's not just about transportation

text:
So, a car with a small-ish 4cyl and an auto tranny isn't a car to you either then? I mean, there's no "roar" and you can't change gears.

What you're describing sounds way more like an "American Muscle 8 cyl" preference.
Sure, they are fun. But by all means not nearly the definitive "car"

You do realize in the UK they have 4 and 6 cyl cars that put our 8s to shame? I mean, they've got the performance. Does lacking the "roar" make them less too? even with a combustion based engine?

Better yet. What about if Tesla threw a wimpy 2cyl in one of their cars? Is it a "Car" then?

I think you are the one who has a very narrow view on what cars actually are.
It's fine to have your preference. But, it's not fine to tell everyone that your preference is law and is the only valid option. Electric cars are cars.

author: FALprofessional

text:
The ultimate fate of the universe is a state of no thermodynamic free energy. Total entropy. Every process in the universe works towards that goal. It's what the universe wants. It wants to burn its energy, fast.

People like Matias and I understand that, be it on a conscious or subconscious level. That's why we rev up, feel the heat, listen to that beautiful sound and inhale that irresistible scent of exhaust. And we are free, calm and truely at peace with ourselves. That slight hint of a smile on our face that you mistake for arrogance but your girlfriend thinks is sexy, it's always there.

So long as we don't turn into uptight, moralistic grudgers that drive electric cars, trying to conserve the status quo, slowing down entropy. The universe doesn't want that. Creeping in a nursing home. Looking out the window all day, alone, incontinent, afraid. It wants to go fast, hot, dirty and loud. We know. That's why the universe loves us and we love it back.

You can't stop Ferris Bueller, Jeannie.

text: Mat√≠as Vidal you are obsolete and no clue about the state of the industry. Electric Motors & Semi Autonomy is simply the inevitable future that every major automotive company has accepted. Fact is Electric Motor vehicles whether Batteries, (Not Hydrogen) Fuel Cells or SuperCapacitor are just better both performance and efficiency. Even if you totally ignore the environmental impact, the simple fact is Financial, Buisness, Operational & Mechanical Cost vs Performance is way better with Electric Motors. You try to Daily Street a 800HP I.C.E. car it is just too stupid expensive. EVs can easily be Street Legal reliable 800+ HP.

text: The motors were developed on the Atieva Edna. Lucid chose to DeTune the motors to 1000 Horsepower.
author: Neojhun

text: There is no "tuning" in a electric cars. It is all about the configuration of the batteries and how fast power can be drawn from them. Someday an EV car maker will add fast discharge capacitors which could easily boost horsepower to 2000 or more but just a few seconds. Want a production car that can do 1.5 second zero to 60 and 7 second quarter miles? That could happen in the next ten years.
author: Novusod

text: Novusod even though a lot of the configuraitons is done digital and electronicaly. You still have to engineer battery distribution rails, cooling for the that system. Level and Set Thresholds for Cell Voltages. Electric Motors also can be temporarily overloaded for short periods as long you have adequate physical overengineering and cooling. Managing the responsible safe level which you overstress components. All this is a complex balancing act very much a type of Tuning.

text:
Ok so here's a problem with these new vehicles. In the UK the law has just changed, so you're not allowed to touch your phone whilst  driving. Not even if it's in a cradle. You're also not allowed to touch the radio if it controls the phone via Bluetooth. This will result in 6 points on your licence  (12 points you lose your license) & ¬£200 fine. 
How can the law then justify the use of these tablets in these concept cars and Tesla road cars?

text: you can't really say that until you really test the batteries and the screens. There are different types of screens that can be very energy efficient and still look really awesome.
author: Not Me

text: Brian you know what's more energy efficient?Analog controls and one or two screens. Not like this 4 screens with 1 motorized screen.
author: mrYaniii22

text: Still, this doesn't make your argument better. This car won't get its battery sucked by 4 fucking screens, let's be sincere. And the fact that you still whine about this car having no analog controls, it means you're simply not the targeted audience to buy it (even if you had the money to). Go mind your own life, because I'm 100% sure there is a big team of trained engineers that have got an idea what a battery is. I'm also pretty sure they don't need any youtube "experts" to tell them what to do.
author: Not Me

text: Brian what are you talking about?it actually makes my argument better. When you talk about efficiency the less power consumed the better. See it's like a smartphone. The two components that suck up most of the battery juice are the processor and the screen. Now back to the car. If you have less screens, there's less power draw. Besides i suggest analog controls be cause its just better to be fiddling the controls in analog controls than in a flat surface WHILE driving.
author: mrYaniii22

text: I think the difference is so small that they had no need to use less screens. I am pretty sure that they have a good team of engineers that thinks about all these things. Yes, there is less power draw, BUT, if they can afford to add more screens, that means that the drawn power is so small that it doesn't really matter.
author: Not Me

text: Brian sure it maybe small who knows but those screens are on for extended periods of time and the power draw could be significant. For an electric car every power draw is important.
author: mrYaniii22

text: "could be". I'm pretty sure there's already someone in that company that thought about this. This discussion is useless. So let's end it.
author: Not Me

text: I agree on too many screens, but the impact on battery drain is marginal at best.

text:
I was a bit more impressed with the Model X interior quality/fit and finish than the S but then again that is now an even higher price bracket Tesla has to compete in than the S so the standards are still not up to par for that price.

When the new Audi Q7 or MB GLS or Cayenne or even the new Volvo XC90 and Jaguar F Pace SUV's have raised their game so much with prices half that of a fully loaded Model S or X, you really have to question what your Tesla money is getting you.

I suspect we will see many aspects of this Lucid with regards to the interior toned down to save cost unless they are trying to appeal to a Bentley or RR buyer looking to spend $300K+ but even then their target is Tesla and if they can at least outdo them that will be enough to attract attention.

author: SystemRichie

text:
Not all electric power is clean, and while it is more efficient regardless, the carbon footprint up front will take some time to be offset - making of the battery is heavy on the carbon footprint, recharging either saves the environment / carbon footprint a little or a lot depending on electric power source, but it isn't automatically better for the world without context. For people who's simply gonna switch a car every 2-4 years, it won't even offset the difference. Worse if their electric power is from coal plants. 

Moreover, while the idea is good on paper, and I have no doubt it will only get increasingly better and mainstream in the future, right now electric vehicle is not ready to replace the market. The luxury (such as what this is trying to do) is not there, this is a 200k car with chairs that don't look half as comfortable (no massaging either?) as a merc S class or Bentley. Nor as luxurious and tech heavy (yes, luxury tech in S class is a plenty) despite them trying so hard. You look at this and think it's well-made, but then go to a store and try sitting inside a S class or Bentley. The "performance" is also mostly for young people who enjoy penis measureing contest with 0-60 and all that, none of the electric cars actually drive well if you track or do spirited driving. Have you tried drifting a tesla? They are absolutely not a driver's car, sure one day we will all live on auto-driving cars, but that day is not today, some people still enjoy driving on challenging roads / tracks with a dynamic car. Last but not least is the cost, I'm sure outside of youtube shit talkers, not as many people care about "super luxury" or "track day driving dynamic". For the majority  it's simply about cost. I'm sure the Tesla 3 will cause more conversions. It's still not dirt cheap level yet.

text: SystemRichie Maybe because an electric car takes an hour to half way charge, while a gas car takes 1 minute to get full. Also these batteries are horrible for the environment, and they are more dependable than these cars, because they are tried and tested.

text: I think your data is a bit outdated. U.S hasn't gotten a majority of its power from coal in years. Natural gas has completely taken over the market, and renewables are rising. To say that the power used to charge ones car in the U.S is just as dirty as a petrol engine is a bit misleading nowadays.
author: Harvey

text: I said it depended on context, and the world doesn't only revolve around the US, that was more of a "extreme bad case". But OK, I agree our implied context here is in the States, but natural gas aren't exactly the best compared to other clean energy. Hydro still cause huge environmental impact initially (well with a dam, not sure about those sea ones), and solar and wind is still not big in the game. Sadly, people and government have such issues with nuclear, otherwise it'd be a great main source during the conversions to other sustainable sources. I do believe we can rely on clean and cheap resources in the foreseeable future. I just don't like people who think eletric = OBVIOUSLY 100X BETTER. I did a paper on the carbon footprint of electrical vehicle back when I was still in electrical engineering before I switched to something else. Heh.

The price of this tech will come down, and it will trickle down to lower-end vehicles. However, I get the sense the Lucid is doing more than Tesla to cater to the type of buyer that plunks 6 figures down on a car.

text: Electric luxury cars are the future of luxury cars is not necessarily a true statement. Just look at how the watch industry progressed, I am particularly referring to rolex. Rolex is a mechanical watch that is easily out performed by digital watches, which can arguably last longer(no moving parts), are cheaper to manufacture and I dare say are more accurate, but rolex is still the pinnacle of luxury and a status symbol.
author: Boris Bagryanskiy

text:
Boris Bagryanskiy Rolex doesn't output burnt chimney fumes out of a tailpipe. 

You could apply the same design aesthetics with an electric drivetrain.

And btw Bentley is looking for feedback on their electric concept.
author: azalru

text: Some people don't care about the environment don't forget that especially when you are rich. Also an ICE car is characteristically different then an electric one, for one being the roar of the engine when you Rev up. Another point you are over looking is that the complexity of certain ICE vehicles in the luxury/performance category - the multitude of moving parts associated with the drive train will make them expensive relative to future electric vehicles pending the affordability of battery technology in the coming years. This will just like in the case of Rolex feed into the fallacy of appealing to wealth where "more expensive is better". Yet another point, don't forget that ICE innovations are not stagnating, things like homogenous charge compression ignition will improve thermal efficiency of ICEs to 70+mpg maintaining their presence in a matured petroluem market
author: Boris Bagryanskiy

text:
Boris Bagryanskiy Some people don't care about the environment when buying the latest smartphone, rolex, HDTV, and electric car that has no tailpipe. 

That is the important thing here, none of these products have any soot traits. 

An electric Bentley still applies to the "expensive branding" much like Rolex. 

Ice hasn't seen any major improvements past 25% efficiency. New ice cars will be valued less than electric much like CRTs and hdds to HDTV, and ssd. The old ones will be in a museum, but the market by large will be electric Luxury vehicles.
author: azalru

text: Are you sure about the 25%?  Hyundai kappa 1.6l engine has 40% thermal efficiency, toyota 1.8l 2ZR-FXE also 40% effiency. Mazda3 is slated to bring the first hcci to the market in 2018, according to them improving the thermal efficiency by 30% based on current efficient engine designs, which will in fact push the mpg much higher then the 60mpg delivered by the current best - Hyundai ioniq. I don't know why you are so focused on "soot trails" most of the market will in fact move away from ICEs but there is a good chance that a large portion of the luxury market will remain gasoline based, because of its history, preference, characterists, etc. That's also another reason why your environmental argument will be marginalised because in a dimished gasoline car market a consumer will be more inclined to believe "I'm just one of the few of the many others", rationalizing the purchase since the luxury market is not as big compared to numbers of sales in other car categories. Also do you your research before throwing out random numbers, it seems you are more so giving your sentiments rather than facts
author: Boris Bagryanskiy

text:
Boris Bagryanskiy According to the google ICe have a maximum thermal efficiency of about 25% to 30% when used to power a car. 0mpg at idle, and way worse efficiency in stop and go traffic. 

Another thing European mpg cycles are way more lenient than in the USA. So those engines are 30% at best.

And they'll never do 0-60 in 2.2 seconds and get over a 100mpge. 


Electric cars use energy only when needed to move a simple rotor. 

People care about not having to deal with soot from their products, hence the popularity of evs. 

Much like the car out phasing the horse carriage which had been around much longer and much more familiar to people than the car itself. 

People still have horses today but not on a grand scale. Same with Ice vehicles, and Koenigsegg agrees that electric vehicles are the masses preferred form of transportation and Ice will relocated to a niche group.

It appears you like to focus on sentiments when you keep wishing ice to have higher mpg, but hybrids with electric motors assisting, and pure electric destroys them in efficiency.

Again most people bought an EV because it's the better product that does not have soot and fumes. Environmentally‚Äã friendliness are for the few with solar panels.
author: azalru

text: Im not sure what you mean by "according to google" because I just listed 2 examples of engines that achieve thermal efficiency of 40%. Also dont get me wrong I think its great that electric cars will be phasing out ICE out of the majority of the market, I just do not think it is realistic to think that the luxury car market would be supplanted by electric vehicles as quickly as is suggested in this video implicating lucid air's potential with the top contenders being ICE based cars for a long time. I have already stated why, the environmental argument is probably the weakest here and so is the fuel economy of the vehicle(I was only relating the feasibility of an ICE by reminding you mpg is only improving). When someone is rich enough to afford 300k bentley mulsanne I think considering the fuel economy and more importantly propriety tax on the vehicle is not something of grave concern given the person's deep pockets to make the purchase in the first place
author: Boris Bagryanskiy

text:
The ONLY problem I have right now with Electric cars, is that they are MORE environmentally damaging than gasoline powered ones.

The means by which they GET their electricity, actually takes up far more in terns of environmentally damaging sources than regular ones do. The means of generating the power for these types of cars actually does much more damage to the planetary ecology for humans than gas cars do, at the moment.

Until that changes, anyone using an electrically powered c ar is actually doing far, FAR, more damage to the Earth for humans than the ones using gasoline powered ones.

author: weinerschnitzelboy

text:
Renato Pascoal Yeah I am definately looking forward to electric cars of european brands. If they are able to match range and performance of Tesla, Tesla is going to have hard time, since European cars such as Audi, BMW and MB are so much better otherwise.

About that Tesla handling, I would say that they are ok, not terrible but certainly not amazing either, atleast when comparing Tesla Model X to Audi Q7. While Audi is almost as heavy as Tesla, it feels way more nimble and easier in curves. You feel the weight of the car more in Tesla. Its propably because Tesla is such a young company. They dont have the years of experience of building and fine tuning car chassis and suspension that european brands such as Audi and BMW have. 

And thats why I feel like Tesla is going to have hard time in future if brands like BMW and Audi can catch up in battery and electric engine technology. Why would you buy expensive Tesla with mediocre handling and mediocre interior when you can have something with similar performance, better handling, higher quality interior, and propably  with better reliability. 
If you are looking for high end electric car and considering Tesla I would wait for year or two and see what europeans can come up with. Tesla is cool brand but imo they will be doomed if europeans can catch up with Tesla in technology. But if Tesla goes the way of dodo, it will always be remembered as a the brand who started the revolution of electric cars and that is already quite something.

author: Luq Shah

text:
@Seventies were the best yeah well, you know the world is a very complicated place. These European car makers are too. Germans even more. An American brand develops a car, tests it, says "it's perfect, put a price tag on it". A German company develops a car,  tests it, says "it's not good enough" and they go back to the drawing board. 
Besides just like you said Tesla is the new kid on block, they don't have decades of experience. So of course they still have to deal with some issues, that are still acceptable. We can't say tesla sucks and we can't say tesla is reliable. Still not enough time to really judge them. Model X silly doors issues are typical of a first gen product. They still learning. What tesla is, is the vision of a very decent human being that wants the best for us while other carmakers want the best for their own interests. I really don't want to see tesla going the way of dodo. And I think they won't. Because when carmakers like BMW and Audi and Mercedes decide that they want to make a car like tesla it will be even more expensive than tesla. Coz at this point they still don't want to come out with a car like that. Tesla didn't find gold where others couldn't. Like I said world is a very complicated place and there's a lot of interests and powers behind the car industry and behind governments. The world belongs to and is run by big corporations. Cars like tesla is not what those big hot shots want right now. Many carmakers already showed in the past that they can do it if they want. It's not a coincidence the first wave of electric cars from major car makers were/ are as ugly AF. They just don't want to sell them. Teslas autopilot? It's a joke compared to what Audi and BMW already showed in the past with cars going around a track at racing speed. Or going up Pikes peak. Or driving themselves to CES, Las Vegas, using turning signals and changing lanes taking over other cars and trucks by them selves. Or like I mentioned before that SLS electric. They can build those kind of cars. Sport electric cars, regular family electric  cars, small electric city cars. But so far they only come up with stuff people don't want to buy or can't afford to buy. They can if they want to. But so far they just been teasing us with products they don't wanna sell to fool us, saying that is the direction they want to go in the future. Tesla didn't find any rare blueprints no one else have, they already gave us and showed us that it's possible to build a good looking electric car with very decent autonomy.

author: Jason van

text: I've been monitoring their actions for years, this is a Nokia/Kodak moment, their upper hand is non existent, they don't own the tech for batteries, they don't own the tech for the best electric motors, they don't own the tech for the best inverter/converter or BMS. All they have is the liability of billions upon billions of existing factories tooled to make ICE cars only with most of their employees having little to no expertise in making EVs. It's not enough to start making an non compliance electric car, they will have to match or do better than the competition. There is no company in the world that will make the batteries for them in the amount needed to make tens of millions of electric cars per year and they're not making enough investments to build them either, Tesla is as well as other Chinese companies. It's so easy to predict what will happen to the likes of VW, they'll lose more and more market share until they'll be forced to sell. It happened to most car companies ever created, most of them made ICE cars. Their plans is to maybe launch something by 2020 but the specs leaked or revealed so far don't ensure they'll be competitive. Why would someone buy an EQ with less than 100 kWh when Lucid Motors and Faraday Future will offer 130 kWh and better acceleration? Why would someone buy a Mercedes SLS or Porsche Mission E when they are or will be slower than what Tesla already offers? They haven't proven themselves to be competitive, they haven't made the investments needed for the battery production. It's just brave talk and no substance.

text: You're still thinking it will be a linear transition, it won't. It will happen in an S curve, first the enthusiasts (has already happened), then people wait for the technology to be affordable and there is a dip in sales (has already happened and is underway as incentives get terminated) and then it gets exponential (this will happen by the early 2020s). By 2030, most new cars will be electric.

author: LongAndLost

text: News flash, China is now the world leader in EV adoption and is pushing car makers the most. Norway is a good example of what happens when there are a lot of incentives. Netherlands, (or was it Denmark?) was a great example of what happens when those incentives get pulled and the technology isn't cheap enough or practical. That's the reality of today, it's not cheap enough and practical but it's almost there, around 60 kWh and 150 kW charging is good enough and those are achievable right now at price points affordable in the developed world. By 2025 the price point of such an EV will drop to between $10000 and $20000 and it will be the start of the end. This is just based on battery prices, no other data needed.
author: eternitynaut

Denmark did exactly what I said

author: LongAndLost

text: Reread my comments and search what an S curve is when it comes to technology adoption. You've clearly missed everything I said. The case of Norway vs Denmark showcases that we are just before the vertical climb in the S curve, now it's the dip, the chasm, after early adopters bought electric cars. The case of China being a leader now in terms of EV adoption is unquestionable. The motivation is fixing air pollution not to sell more cars because they make lots of cars. Sure they want a strong domestic market but they want it to be electric above all else, a clear distinction. As for VW being behind the cutting edge is beyond madness to doubt considering what they offer right now and what they showcased as their concepts for 2020 and beyond. They're playing catch up in the 2020s for what is already available. They have nothing.
author: eternitynaut

text: kalimul I understand what you say. But it isn't an S curve. I am not gonna make any claims before I see Tesla enter other markets. This behaviour was expected in the markets they are currently in. For electric cars to increment their market share in the form of an S curve they must quickly become More convenient and cheaper for a larger consumer base. They are neither of these things. Even in the US superchargers aren't that wide spread or convenient. In southern and eastern Europe as well as middle East people live in apartments most of the time without a dedicated garage(hence no easy connection to an outlet). How many of the southern and middle eastern countries are willing to push these advancements ?
author: LongAndLost

text: That's why I said, again, we're just before the vertical climb, we're not in the vertical climb because if we were, we wouldn't be having this conversation, we could just go outside and figure it out by looking at cars. They are becoming affordable due to battery price dropping constantly, it's several times cheaper than what it was even 3 years ago per kWh and it's expected to drop even more once large factories are finished. The thing is, it takes economy of scale that only millions of units produced per year can enable, factories needed are just now being in construction. But who builds them?  Not VW, not Mercedes, not GM, not even Nissan or Renault. It's by companies that make batteries in Asia and in the U.S. it's mostly just Tesla. Europe and Africa are a wasteland. South America at least has great plans for battery manufacturing enabled by local reserves of lithium.
author: eternitynaut

text: kalimul China is leading in production size. Where did I contradict that. There is also no reason for them to not sell batteries to VW. I still fail to see how Tesla is 10 years ahead of VW. Their battery tech is still years old because batteries really haven't improved since late 80s/early 90s. Production size is something VW can deal with. VW also has the upper hand in branding and line up. Even if VW enters the other markets I mentioned late people are more inclined to buy from VW Group than Tesla. I mean Hyundai produces S classes for cheaper and who buys those outside of Korea?
author: LongAndLost

text:
There's not enough for everyone, that's was the reason why I said they, VW and any other car maker has to build their own battery plants if they want to keep up. When one company makes and sells millions of electric cars, the economy of scale they achieve can't be matched by someone making a couple hundred of thousands of units. Even if they buy from others, larger orders get priority and better bulk discounts. As for Chinese state support for EVs, here

https://electrek.co/2016/10/31/china-pushing-aggressive-zev-mandate-8-of-new-cars-to-be-electric-by-2018-12-by-2020/

Regarding technological capabilities, browse their website and try to find any 100 kWh electric car.  How about performance, can you find an EV they make with under 2.6 s from 0 to 100 kmph? Are they planning on releasing anything close to that? No? Well then.

Regarding battery chemistries not improving, that's the most ridiculous claim I've ever heard. When Tesla made the Roadster the batteries they used had 117 Wh/kg and 370 Wh/L. Today they have around  250 Wh/kg and over 600 Wh/l. Even if they hadn't improved, the price has dropped almost 10 times in a decade.

author: Nathan Curet

text: Nicolas Ruck    Most people that say this tend to be people that live in a big city where traffic is one of the most stressful thing they have to deal with on a daily basis. But because you think it will work for yourself, you think it will work for the rest of the country. Well it will not. This idea of self driving only with no stop signs or stop lights will never happen. Now I understand city people's frustration with traffic, but it will go down without every car being self driving due to the rise of ride sharing that will happen in big cities. Fewer cars on the street. But your never going to have every single car self driving. The only thing that would solve over optional self driving is traffic and like I said, that will improve. There are many reasons that we will keep the option to drive like the need of a manual backup, hacking, utility of vehicles that's not just getting people from A to B in well developed areas, there will always be situations and places where a human will need to drive, and yes the big one for a lot of people, many still love to drive.

author: azalru

text:
azalru 
Now try to find an electric car that is as luxurious as an S-Class or BMW 7 Series. Tailpipes are not considered ugly, as this comes down to personal preference. I know more than enough people with this type of car that would never want an electric one because of the problems they have. Electric cars need to charge at least as fast as you could fill up your tank with gas. They also should look like normal cars, not like a disabled alien that had a hard crash while landing on earth. Like seriously, wtf is that giant tablet in that Tesla? It's way too modern to be considered as luxurious. 

First they have to figure out how to make them as reliable and good looking as normal cars before they start competing with big brands. There is no way in hell that a president could stop for 30 Minutes just to charge the car up to 80%. 

If it comes to noise, the inside of the newest S-Class is still less noisy than the Tesla but if you want to hit the pedal, you'll hear it pretty good, which is great. It's isolated way better than any of the competing electric cars. 

Electric cars need to catch up with the times, because for now, petrol cars still deliver way more.
author: Phillip Lewicki

text:
Phillip Lewicki Way more horseshit out of the tailpipe. Not one of them of a full tank everyday out the garage.

No summon features without engine startup delay, and no keybutton holding. 

No clutter free interior like ultra modern houses. Ask any engineer , knobs and buttons are ugly, and as trends show the iPhone and it's clones are the norm, while blackberry/Mercedes and nokia/bmw are outdated.

Also no level 5 Selfdriving along ,less cargo space, less passenger space especially in a m5 size format unlike from the Lucid Air which has has alot more to play with no gas tank and emission drivetrain.

Also 700kw of superchargering from Tesla and Porsche is bragging about under 5 minute fastcharging 5 minutes for long distance roadtrips. 

Also taking your car for emission inspections and driving a certain amount of miles to reset a couple of monitors , ugly gas stations that make you pump gas like a blue collar worker. Just going there is revolting. But it's mandatory even in the cold winter and scorching heat, and you smell the fumes too as you handle dinojuice. 

Luxury ev owners get out of the garage never caring about the range or weather, and already preheated with worrying about dying from toxic fumes.

Looks no matter how much you complain about the inevitability of modern tech much like Oled hdtv replacing CRT TVs, smartphones replacing landlines/ rotary phones , LED lights replacing kerosene lamps, it's happening, and you can't do anything about it besides going to niche meetups about old classic gas carriages.

text: @azalru Dude, electric isn't the future of cars. Maybe a form of hybrid, but not pure electric. The chemical waste and emissions from powerplants would be catastrophic to our environment if everyone in America alone drove only electric or only gas. We might face meltdowns due to excessive burn of plutonium rods, and destruction of wildlife due to runoff. Hybrid systems or an alternate fuel are the future.
author: D. E. Bodiford

text:
azalru 
The majority of people doesn't give a shit about how the tailpipe looks. There are more people liking a loud and good sounding, sexy looking Akrapovic exhaust than people who don't. Just because you don't like it, doesn't mean that others also don't.

Numbers like this don't mean shit, it's the amount of cars that are actually driven and not how many are bought. 

I am not a hater of electric cars, especially because the idea of it is great but for now, they just simply can't deliver. It's the truth. Saying that buttons and knobs are outdated is bullshit. That screen is going to get smudged up in no time. Electric cars have to look normal. Look at the hybrids BMW, Mercedes, Audi or Porsche does. They look way more pleasurable and also have a much better fit and finish of materials than it's Tesla counterparts. The claimed range of Tesla is just really really bad. There were dozens of tests that have shown that it doesn't have a range that big. 

As I said, electric cars aren't refined enough to hit the "mainstream" market, especially here in Europe where people have very high expectations for their cars. It's going to take a really long time for these cars to get good and for the infrastructure to get "adjusted" for them (you'll need many charging stations. By many I mean a crap load of them). Until autonomous driving will be a big thing it's going to take even longer, so don't get too happy about what Tesla has to offer, because that's not enough for our market.

text:
D. E. Bodiford According to the Union of Concerned scientists the grid is getting is more and more efficient every year. 

As Tesla solar roofs and powerwalls(among other home battery solutions from LG, Mercedes etc) keep on growing , power for  Electric cars won't be an issue. 

Look at the Kauai Tesla Video, already offsetting diesel pollution. Or China with no engine, that space is used for bioweapon defense mode that cleans the interior air, and a bit of the outside.

Hybrids are complicated and still need to be maintained to the emission standard, which millions of them are worse along with being spread out than a regulated secluded powerplant.

There's no choice with hybrids, you can't run on solar panels,hydro , or other cleaner alternatives. You always go back to the antiquated gas pump.
